Diet & Body Re-composition

Initial Body Fat and Body Composition Changes

General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets
Read the above articles, and decide whether you need to bulk (add muscle), cut (lose fat), or maintain.

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>>69829746
Best way to start any cut or bodyfat reduction is to understand your starting point.
Understand how tall you are, how much you weigh and how many calories you need to eat per day, your total daily energy expenditure or TDEE. Cutting is a very serious and delicate process. The more effort you put into your cut, the better your progress and the smaller chance of relapsing

starting point
>height
>weight
>TDEE
TDEE can be calculated here
https://tdeecalculator.net
ALWAYS set your activity level to sedentary. Any other activity level will skew your calorie goals and you may or may not see progress. It's better to overshoot and eat less, than to understood and eat too much.

For instance. Me
>5'7
>160
>TDEE - 1950

The next step is to subtract 500 from your calculated TDEE. Weight loss happens when you eat less than maintenance. It's been scientifically calculated that -3500 calories a week equates to 1lb of weight loss. So take -3500/7 days of the week, you get -500 each day. That's easy as fuck. 500 calories is a bowl of chips, a burger, 1 chocolate bar.
You can go 7 days a week eating one less chocolate bar each day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69829952
So with -500. My new TDEE required to lose 1lb a week is now 1450
>1950 - 500 = 1450 calories a day

>1450 calories a day? Anon you're going to starve
Yes and no. You won't starve, but you SHOULD be hungry. Hungry is a good thing. It's a sign that your body is going through changes. When you're hungry, your body is expending energy, burning fat, and making you thinner. It's important to let your body use your stored resources (aka fat) instead of eating.

>What should I eat?
It's important to remember that what you eat is SECOND to how much you're eating, yet they are both important. Don't overthinks, overthink your calorie intake.

You could eat a big burger thats 1450 everyday as your only meal but also the best results will always come with a balanced diet. Eating rice/chicken has been proven to be filling and a good mix of macros. You'll see more progress eating healthy and lean, rather than trying to squeeze junk into your calorie limits.

Ultimately though. 1450 calories is 1450 calories. However you chose to get to that amount is up to you.
Also remember 1450 is my number. Every persons. Every person has their own specific TDEE. So calculate yours and start your thinspo journey today

>>69830115
You're not harming yourself by eating less. The body has many means of keeping itself healthy. Fat storage is one of them. The body will use most of its fat reserves during your cut, and you will remain healthy. The only issues you'll face are minor, or psychological. In either case you need to remember why you're trying to be thin and fight through the hunger.

Anorexia should be reserved for people who are severely underweight to where it'd actually detrimental to their health. -500 calories a day is a laughable diet, but its good enough for beginners to start seeing considerable progress.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>>69831582
>If you’re a beginner runner should you even worry about doing certain things to improve time or just keep running for a while?

Couch to 5k is designed for the beginner runner. It gets you gradually into the swing of things. The "to 5k" part is mostly to motivate people with a goal.

But if you don't want to follow any kind of plan, you can spend a month or so going for runs with little mind for distance or pace (though definitely pay attention if you feel pain) and once you're comfortable you can start training with a little more focus on your own specific goals.

posts.com:
>>69828449
Just get your squat to 1x-1.5x bodyweight, diddle 1.5-2.0x bodyweight, OHP 0.5x-0.75x bodyweight for a solid base.
From this point on, strength in the powershitting movements aren't that important. You should focus on power and stability on one leg.
Do plyometric drills 1.5x/week to focus on power generation. (In the running motion, you are on one leg trying to generate force for like 0.33 seconds, this is very important)
For strength, try to mix in some one-legged movements. walking lunges are probably goat, also one-legged diddle, squat.
A good test for strength/stability on one leg is to see how many single-leg bodyweight calf-raises you can do.

You should think of Z2 miles as fluff miles that allow you to decrease the intensity of some of your miles, while increasing your overall weekly mileage, and thus your base.
To prescribe Z2 at a certain HR region is ill-defined nerd shit. Just think, OK, I want to increase my mileage? Where can I take away some hard miles, where can I put in some (more) easy miles? Simple as that.
Don't make the mistake of thinking Z2 miles are "free". You still need your fucking legs to recover, please.

>>69819796
At the point of being below 20% body fat or so, your muscle to fat ratio is more of a function of your hormones and the biological environment you create. If you keep trying to lose that fat you'll just keep losing muscle along with it and your relative ratio will remain about the same, despite losing lots of weight. Pack on a bunch of muscle first and then cut off the fat by fasting+exercise. It's a lot easier to get to 10%-15% body fat if you have a lot more muscle and are fitter in general

Don't forget to exercise when you fast. No need to go too hard or get a sweat on, just don't stay resting all day.

This was the missing piece of the puzzle for me. It lowers hunger and makes you feel better over all when fasting. I go for walks, lift light weights and do squats all throughout the day in small amounts to keep up my energy levels and feel significantly less hungry. Anyway, just wanted to let everyone know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Stinky edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For rotund individuals who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Spend the next 9 months going hard as fuck. Once the kid is born you have a few options
>Power to the People style high frequency medium intensity programming (ideal if homegym)
>Body part split which will probably be 1 compound + 1-2 assistance movements
>Hard full body session 1x/week (intensity needs to be high- like take sets past failure high)
>Kettlebells/Calisthenics/Etc. You'll get a solid workout in and keep a good baseline level of fitness but you will get smaller
The most important thing though is going to be doing something- even if its just a few pushups- to keep the habit going.

bro you're twenty four and from Europe?
Look into taking a working holiday visa, there are a few different ones, like deals between countries. You get 1 or 2 year full work rights visa to another country like Australia, NZ, Canada, Argentina, Colombia etc...
And once you get there look at the backpacker community, you stay in hostel first when you land, then you can go to a farm job in the country (Aus/NZ) and you can easily make 50k euros working on a farm picking fruit/veggies. It's basically a slave trade deal with european youths going to other countries in exchange for a nice vacation. Most farms they give you lodging, you can sleep and eat there. If you're savvy you can stay 2 years (3 months farm work requirement to get 2nd year) and save like 95% of your checks. I knew a guy that came back with close to 100k euro from his trip.
He just took rides with other backpackers who bought 4x4 to farm jobs, stayed there, went to the beach, lived frugally (no big spender) and when he came back he had enough money to open his own business/deposit for an apartment.

Maybe that's what you need. Look up working holiday visas from your country, the agreements with other countries. You might be able to do that.

In dealing with big emotions, time is your biggest ally. Use time in conjunction with fair compromise (doesn't tread upon your dignity) to reach your ends in a relationship. It's a mix of Machiavellianism and compassionate empathy that yields the best results.

Like, it's totally reasonable for her to demand that you spend your breaks talking with her. You hurt her feelings pretty bad I imagine. If you can get assurance she isn't seeing other guys, like maybe she shares location or something (that is revealing enough without being too invasive, maybe something else will work better just spitballing) does it really matter to you what the relationship is called? The end goal is a long-term relationship so don't get caught up in the day to day dramas.

>>69838695
Eh. Your philosophy is half right. Platitudes like
>Why aren’t you running to do what your nature demands?
belie human nature. And animal nature for that matter. Birds, bees, humans, and everything precisely don't have some natural drive to "work". What even is "work"? You are just positing "productivity" as this abstract thing that really exists in the world, becoming obsessed with it and twisting it into its own goal rather than a tool. This is like, if you take football/soccer as an analogy, the dribbling shenanigans become twisted into being interpreted the "core aim" of the game, rather than actually scoring goals.
In the best case comparison, your philosophy is egging someone to get up, read books, and research cancer cures, vs. lying in bed doomscrolling. But this is hardly what 99% of people would amount to in 99% of cases. They would interpret it as getting up and performing meaningless drone/bullshit work (even if not job-related, such as online presences) as "more valuable" than enjoying yourself, however form that may be. We can debate the merits of that, but not in this post. I am still going on about the overarching philosophy of your point:

If it were possible, any human/animal could be reduced to a state of the comfy-lying-in-bed-anon, it's not a rejection of their fundamental maxims (life without suffering, etc.), but rather a maximum satisfaction of these.

We both agree that the bed-doomscrolling is shit. But I just hate your reasoning for rejecting it. My argument against it would be more like "it doesn't matter what role you or the human species were 'intended/bred' for (rejecting your ideal): what matters is your current higher ideals that say not realizing your dreams/potential is a giant waste".
The difference between our views is that my version is resistant to being corrupted from normie ideas of what a "good life" is supposed to look like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834422
What you're referring to is "recomp" which is putting on muscle without gaining or losing fat. While it's technically possible to go from obese to lean this way, it's very, very, very slow. You'd lose the fat in a quarter of the time if you just did a traditional cut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834487
I don't get way is more efficient to cut and then to bulk rather than recomping.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834548
Recomp means you are not at a caloric deficit, so your body isn't going to burn its fat reserves for energy (You can build muscle slowly this way as your body will use the protein it eats for protein synthesis). If you want to lose bodyfat, the fastest way to do that is to get your body to tap into those reserves for energy as a result of a deficit instead of chipping tiny pieces off while at basically no deficit.

Retard speak: Recomping won't burn fat reserves the way a deficit will.

Thanks homie (from macros guy)
Should that .82 protein per lb based off of your current weight or your goal weight?
Im 193lbs right now, aiming for 175lbs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69835291
You base it off your current weight and bodyfat%. So for example: if you're 23% bodyfat, you'd subtract that from your total weight. In this scenario 23% of 193 is 44 lbs, so you'd subtract that from 193 to get 149. Then you multiply 149 by 0.82 to get the amount of protein you need, 122 in this example.

hope that helps!

posts.com:
>>69839757
This is how I view RPE/RIR. Fresh in a new periodization, I base it off my 1RM=RPE10/RIR0. Say the workout asked for 5 reps @ RPE8/RIR2 - Using a "find your 1rm chart" or my own experience, I know what weights I can do for 7 reps before I hit failure and that is my working weight for that set of 5.

Personally, I prefer using percentages for my blocks (WK1 1RM, WK2 70%, WK3 75%..). It's how I initially learned how to lift and I'm pretty set un my ways. However, I do prefer the occasional RPE flexibility: What is hard for me at this level TODAY? Compared to when I last did the exercise, I could come in feeling like a champ, and something that was an I before now feels like a 6. Or the opposite; I had shit sleep or I'm sore, so the effort will still be there, but the weight may not be, so I won't feel bad about not hitting my targeted percentages for that day.

I don't know if my ranting made sense, or was any way helpful, but enjoy a Billy on me.

>>69837512
Chicken, turkey, milk, eggs (depending where you live), beans, and lentils. You can get by on less protein but you can't go super low protein or you'll take forever to recover and spin your wheels. You can go as low as 0.6g/pound of body weight in protein per day and still get some good results
>>69837410
>18 years old
>what's the optimal routine for me
You'll grow on basically any program right now. If you can't afford a gym hit up your local park and do a lot of dips, pullups, handstands, and squats. Go for a lot of volume on those 3 days per week. Spam the shit out of them because if you can't increase the weight you have to increase the reps. If you can afford a gym membership then try a full body bodybuilding routine 3 days per week as a starting point instead. 1 lift for the chest, legs, back, shoulders, and 2 for the arms (you have two separate muscles to work). You also need to give the rear delt (back of the shoulder) some love too because it's one of the most important muscles for aesthetics and doesn't get hit that hard by most big compound exercises.
>Here's an example day
Deadlift 4x3-6

Bench Press 4x6-10

Chinups 3xFailure

Seated Dumbbell OHP 4x8-12

GIANTSET x3
Curl of Choice 8-12
Incline Skull Crusher 8-12
Rear Delt Raises 10-15

The first number is how many sets to do. The range after is how many reps you should lift it for, and when you can hit the top of that range on your first set with the rest of your reps falling within the range, increase the weight. A giantset is doing them back to back without rest and taking your rest period after you get through the whole giantset.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For diet:

I recommend chicken and rice. At least 50/50 ratio of chicken to rice per meal. If you're eating 500g to 1kg of chicken a day you'll build muscle.

For exercise:

Just do whatever you want, but also try to get in a few hundred pushups per day every morning and before bed. Like 500 pushups a day + gym will build good muscle. Start off with sets of 30 to 40 reps, eventually you'll be able to do 100 straight. It's a good exercise for building arms and chest and shoulders.

For gym:

Do whatever you want it literally doesn't even matter, you will grow. Don't skip legs.

For cardio:

Try to run 30 to 50 miles a week at a good pace, like 90 to 95% of your max speed. It's good for fat loss and building endurance. Also good for building legs.

Also, try to reduce stress and get enough sleep. Super important for growth long term. Make sure you eat enough food every day. Good luck bro, we're all gonna make it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The basic calisthenics movements (pullups, chinups, dips, leg raises and their variations) can build muscle, but have diminishing returns once you can easily go over the hypertrophy (8-12 rep) range, so calisthenics alone can give only this much muscle.
Calisthenics alone are a meme for muscle building.
That's why you want to do WEIGHTED calisthenics with a vest/backpack/ankle weights/dipping belt/whatever. As long as you are on a progressive overload in the hypertrophy rep range, you will build muscle mass.
And if you are doing calisthenics, you don't need to do meme exercises like the iron cross, maltese cross, planches, etc. if your goal is to have larger muscle mass, simple movements are more than enough.

>t. primary workout method is rings and weighted calisthenics

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69840734
Yes and no, for any specific part isolations are usually better. However compounds are very time efficient, if you only do flyes you have to spend an equal amount on triceps exercises etc, while if you do heavy dumbbell presses you will hit both the pecs, shoulders and triceps at the same time.

The total volume you can get on your muscles in one gym session is maximized by doing compounds. Most successful bodybuilders do both.

Note that compound does not mean "barbell exercises", a pressing machine is a compound just as much as a barbell press is.

I didn't attend dancing classes like she told me too, but I did yoga instead. I also went to a swimming pool near the psychiatric hospital everyday, then went to aroma therapy where I relaxed in a big comfy chair while sniffing some fucking lavender or whatever. Then I went to her office and we chatted about this and that. The drug eventually kicked in and she suggested lowering my dose to a minimum. Now I take it every day till maybe next year. Live never was better. I'm calm all the time and get my shit done. Maybe I was lucky that I had a good doctor who knew what I needed and even recommended me a good pill that doesn't fuck me up.

posts.com:
>>69840650
Sounds like what you need is a good plyometric workout. You can google some stuff but here’s what I would start with.

4 sets of weighted clap pushups x failure (really helps your jab and cross be more explosive)
4 sets weighted jump squats x failure (good for explosive foot work)
3 rounds (2-3 minutes) of weighted foot work/shadow boxing drills. You can use a weight vest/dumbbells or both.
3 sets of pull ups x failure. This is the only one that’s not really a plyometric but it will help balance out the rest of your physique.

May not sound like much but if this is a supplemental workout it should improve your performance, speed, and power. You can progressively overload all of these as well. Just don’t sacrifice form for more weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69836963
Your body needs X amount of energy to maintain everything in your body. If you dont eat enough to provide X energy, it will take it from your fat and muscle stores. If you have more of one than the other, it prefers to take it from that source. You can, then "recomp," that is, eat at a deficit and burn fat while building muscle, if you have enough fat and little enough muscle to do it. If the opposite is true, it will burn your muscle for energy instead (or more of it than otherwise). That's catabolism, and you can't grow when you're like that.

Eventually, you end up with too much muscle compared to your fat, and it doesn't work as well. It becomes painfully slow, even with perfect meal timing, workout plan, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69836963
>>69837068
Additiomally, you need to realize it's not just protein that's rewuired to build muscle. It's protein AND energy. Being in a deficit eventually means you don't have the energy required to build muscle, even if the protein is there.

posts.com: The most common side effect of MGA is weight gain, with an incidence of 15 to 70% at the high dosages used to treat breast cancer.[4][5] Other side effects include vaginal bleeding (7–8%), nausea (7%), and edema (5%), as well as others such as dizziness and shortness of breath.[4][5][64] MGA can cause hypogonadism and associated symptoms like diminished secondary sexual characteristics, sexual dysfunction, osteoporosis, and reversible infertility in men and premenopausal women.[65][66][67] Combining MGA with an androgen/anabolic steroid like oxandrolone, nandrolone decanoate, or testosterone in men can alleviate MGA-associated symptoms of hypoandrogenism as well as further increase appetite and weight gain.[66][68][69][70] Less common but more serious side effects of MGA include cardiovascular/thromboembolic complications such as thrombophlebitis.[4] It may also cause glucocorticoid side effects such as Cushing syndrome-like symptoms, steroid diabetes, and adrenal insufficiency at high dosages.[71][72][73] Case reports of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, jaundice, intrahepatic cholestasis, and meningiomas in association with high-dosage MGA have been published.[74][75][76][77] In older patients who take MGA, one in 23 will have an adverse event leading to death.[78]

>>69830519
Anon, most people trend towards comfort instead of discomfort. They will take the easy path, or the path of least resistance. Even people who appear disciplined in other areas can be weak in unexpected ways. As you get older, you gain more responsibilities and things which threaten to take up your time:

1. Work
2. Education (either college age, or going to night-school while working)
3. Spouses (needy wives or husbands)
4. Children (one of the biggest time constraints)
5. Hobbies
6. Family (extended family)

There are 24 hours in a day. On weekdays you might get up at 7 or 8, work from 9 to 5, spend time with your kids until their bedtime, then spend time with your spouse or engage in a hobby before going to sleep. That's not even mentioning stuff like cooking meals, going to the grocery store, going to doctor's appointments for yourself or your kids. On the weekends you might have "plans" that eat up the time that work normally does. Visiting family, taking your kids somewhere fun, cleaning and maintaining your home. Between all of these things, it can be difficult for people to force themselves into working out, especially if they haven't done it for a while, since initially there will be some discomfort.

Squeezing an extra hour or so into your morning before work or cooking breakfast for yourself/others isn't impossible, but it's uncomfortable and difficult. So the diligent, motivated, and driven will make time. The lazy, weak, excuse filled people who lack fortitude will not. Meal prep? Ugh that's too difficult with stressful work and children - better just pick up fast food! Exercise in the morning? Ugh, I hate getting up early and feeling tired before the day even begins! Work out at night? Are you crazy? I'm tired and just want to sit on the couch and relax!

So it goes on and on, year after year, getting fatter, weaker, lazier. Their metabolisms slow, their gluttony increases, they turn into fat fucks.

>>69830519
It’s the compounded effect of too much shit food on the body.
Insulin resistance increases over time with bad diet, meaning a fat’s insulin spikes higher and remains higher to accomplish the same thing it did when they were young. High insulin limits your body’s ability to access its fat stores because insulin signals for energy storage. This also makes the fat hungry sooner because everyone’s body burns glucose before fat, and when a fat’s body starts to run low on glucose it can’t switch to fat burning because their insulin is still high, signaling to store fat, so they become hungry again because their body can’t access the hundreds of thousands of stored calories in their gunt. The thing is as soon as someone has a gut they are somewhat insulin resistant (it’s a sliding scale from overweight to type 2 diabetic), but insulin resistance can be reversed pretty easily with diet plus time.

>>69830897
I'd add that for most people this is very easy to just slip into. It isn't something that happens overnight like flipping a light switch. It's years of choosing comfort and refusing to subject yourself to an additional stressor (exercise or dieting). Being full feels good. Eating increasingly large portions of fried, processed, greasy, sugary "comfort food" goyslop makes them feel good. Physical inactivity feels "good" to them, activity is strenuous and only becomes more so by the day as they get weaker and heavier. They have little energy, and are emotionally dependent on food and inactivity to cope with the other more unavoidable activities in their day.

The hardest habits for most people to form are also those which don't have an immediate reward. If you're fat and you diet for a day and aren't instantly skinny, their weak minds start writhing in agony and questioning what the point of depriving themselves for a single day was. It may take days, weeks, months, or years to reverse the damage they've caused, and for most people hitting any form of obstacle and discomfort is enough to make them turn tail and run. Same goes for working out. I know plenty of 40-something skinny-fats who aren't necessarily lazy and gluttonous, but are putting on weight because of their inactivity and metabolic changes. They've never exercised, never been to a gym, hate the feeling of physical exertion and will do pretty much anything to avoid it.

There is a point of no return in my opinion. Either you've developed healthy habits and are in shape by the time you're 40, or you never will be. Sure there are probably exceptions, but good luck building baseline muscle over age 40. Good luck reversing half a lifetime's worth of bad habits over age 40. The only ones who do are doing it because of health scares and realizing they're going to die young if they don't make drastic changes.

>>69834741
This isn't a lie. You won't find a single athlete or body builder that recommends not eating or skipping meals to drop body fat, except for fighters who cut weight immediately before a fight. It does put you into starvation mode, and an over-deficit just makes you lose more muscle than body fat, which cuts your metabolism (since muscle burns more calories than fat) and starts the process of yo-yo weight loss and regain.
What the nurse should have told her was, "Skipping meals is fucking stupid. Eat 5 to 6 small meals a day that reach your target calorie goal, once every 3ish hours. At the same time, you need to start exercising, preferably by lifting weights. You need to build muscle mass, especially in the core and legs, so you actually raise your metabolism. You'll start to see body fat loss, but don't expect instantaneous results."

Most guys can get along with most guys across a wide spectrum of implied hierarchical status. A fat anime geek and good looking high status man can usually easily cooperate and be friendly to achieve a task or objective, even if they normally wouldn't associate socially with each other.

With women if you want the same result, you have to demonstrate equal or above status to get a similar response. Your looks and body language in that exact moment decide how they will treat and interact with you. This very often even applies to mundane and everyday things like getting service in a store, never mind recreational social activities.

I am good looking and have charisma, but I am 5'10". So using myself as an example;
>women of equal height or shorter treats me very well, are friendly and cooperative
>women of medium to high attractiveness that are taller are more dismissive
>women that are taller but with obvious deficiencies in other criteria (face, weight etc) tends to treat me well
Of course there are exceptions, but you see the trend and point here?
The ones that identify me as a possible sexual or at least social/sexual adjacent partner treats me well. The ones who don't are dismissive.
Meanwhile with guys, this isn't a factor.
Me and some other guy don't need to perceive each other as social equals at all to cooperate and be friendly.
It also makes sense why so many girls spend so much time every morning getting caked up in makeup and having an elaborate system of different wardrobes. They probably treat each other in the exact same manner, so in their eyes this is a prerequisite for basic cooperative functioning.

there was a time where i was only lifting 2x a week, my progress did reduce but it didnt stop completely. id just stick to the basics, 2 push exercises, 2 pull exercises, one accessory and one leg exercise per workout. better to do lower range reps, 5ish for 3-4 sets. you just have to plan it out to hit every muscle as often as possible, use a lot of compounds. tactical barbell has a program for 2x a week but its too "simple" for me personally, just do your own routine

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69840762
you just need to space it out. the principle remains the same, i guess it does take a good bit of time on the lift days (i usually spent like 1h30 or longer) and you need to specifically time your lifts by priority, type, and put legs & accessory in between to extend rest time for your upper body muscles. generally speaking, for example, the big important lifts for upper body (OHP, Bench) usually went first, then a leg exercise, then an important pull exercise, then an "unimportant" push exercise, then an accessory, then the "unimportant" pull exercise. i might reverse pull and push sometimes but pull exercises also use a lot of push exercises sometimes, which you definitely notice afterwards.
CNS fatigue also starts being a problem, hence the accessory at the end and the heavy compounds at the beginning

As a long time lifter, I have to say that I am not a fan of ballistics in working out. In my opinion, these types of exercises are not effective for building strength and muscle mass, and can even be dangerous if not performed correctly.

In my experience, traditional weightlifting exercises like squats, deadlifts, and presses are the most effective for building strength and muscle, and have stood the test of time for a reason. Ballistics, on the other hand, are often just a flashy and trendy way for people to try and impress others in the gym, without actually putting in the work to make real progress.

As a long-time lifter, I can tell you with certainty that gym strength absolutely carries over to real life. In fact, I would even go as far as to say that it carries over 110%. I've seen the tangible benefits of my time spent lifting weights in everything from my ability to carry heavy grocery bags, to the way I handle difficult physical tasks at work.

Gym strength gives you a level of functional fitness that you just can't get from other types of exercise. When you lift weights, you're not only building muscle and improving your overall fitness, but you're also improving your physical capability in real-world situations. Whether it's carrying furniture, digging a hole, or even just going for a hike, the strength you build in the gym will serve you well in everyday life.

So, if you're looking to become more confident and capable in your physical abilities, I highly recommend focusing on building gym strength. It will pay dividends in all aspects of your life.

>>69839012
Shoulder abduction (the movement you perform during a lateral raise) is the opposite of shoulder adduction, which is performed by the lats and teres major. Shoulder adduction is a very large component of wide grip pullups/pulldowns, both of which are pulling exercises. Therefore, because shoulder abduction is the opposite movement, it is a push.

Becoming more intimidating requires a combination of self-awareness, self-improvement, and practicing new behaviors. Here are some steps to help you achieve this:

Identify your insecurities and self-doubt. Understanding what holds you back can help you overcome it.

Practice self-care and improve self-esteem. Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself, like exercising, learning a new skill, or having sex.

Learn intimidation skills. This includes putting others down, shutting down their opinions, and breaking boundaries.

Surround yourself with weak and submissive people who can't do anything to you or your goals.

Practice intimidating in everyday interactions. Start with small, low-stakes interactions and gradually build up to more challenging situations.

Reframe negative thoughts and challenge limiting beliefs.

Seek support when needed. Consider therapy or coaching to work on specific issues.

Remember, becoming more intimidating takes time and practice, so be patient with yourself and keep working towards your goal.
